children.subject: Can confirm, Svezda is really great.

history.content:
Math 110 is a good course to take after 16B to deepen your understanding of linear algebra and understand the abstract side of the subject as well. 

I believe that 128 has 120 as a prereq so I assume that you have already taken that? 120 introduces different techniques that allow you to generalize many of the concepts that you have seen in 16B in the finite-dimensional vector case to the infinite-dimensional cases of signals in discrete time as well as signals in continuous time. The concept of circulant matrix in 16B gets replaced with the idea of an LTI system. The DFT gets generalized to the DTFT, CTFT, and Fourier Series. The characteristic polynomial and eigenvalues of a system matrix gets extended to think about the Laplace Transform in which the poles play the roles that eigenvalues do. And so on. These ideas from 120 enable 128 to introduce ways of thinking about control systems that go further than the taste provided in 16B.

Another key course for control theory is 127, optimization.

children.subject: I am taking 120 right now. 128 seems like a really cool class, and I'm quite intent on studying controls. Just not sure when to take it.

Laplace transforms and Fourier analysis are much more important than linear algebra to the level of controls in EE 128. Linear algebra and optimization come into play at the end of the course with LQR control (sort of like least squares control of your state error and input magnitudes), but math 110 is probably much more than you need for that.

history.content:
To add a different data point: I never took Math 110 and don't regret it at all. After seeing eigenvectors over and over again in 20, 40, 120, 127, 128, 145B, 176, 189, 191, it felt quite... enough. I'd say I got most of my linear algebra chops from CS 189 for the undergrad level (it was easy enough to pick up on the way), and then 127 brought it a tiny bit closer to what it's like in the grad level. I would say, if you don't see enough linear algebra going through your EE/CS classes, then I can't imagine you're taking anything that would make having taken 110 worthwhile anyway.

That said, 110 is probably a good class, with lots of reasons to take it. Just saying I wouldn't bother taking it just in the hope that it'll be that useful for EECS classes that use linear algebra; you'll pick it up along the way.

On the other hand, if I had to go back and pick a math course to take to prepare me for EE/CS classes, it would probably be analysis (real or complex). And probably Physics 105... definitely look into that. The calculus of variations is utterly mindblowing.

--- 


I replied below but I'll add to this response. True about the eigenstuff analysis! Honestly learning eigen____ in a purely linear algebra setting is pretty terrible for understanding them. I first took linear algebra in spring 2012 through concurrent enrollment in high school (UCB class of 2017), and it took EE 20, 120, 123, 126, 128, and teaching EE 16 to really understand the point of eigen____.

children.subject: EE 16A/B don't teach any of the Fourier analysis that was in EE 20 except for the DFT.

Huh that's interesting. Granted, 128 didn't use any fourier at all the semester I took it (though I guess laplace is similar). I feel like if you have the mathematical maturity to understand transforms and such you could probably do without 120 (I've taken 128, 106AB without 120, so it's doable) if you don't care about signal processing as much.

TBH 120 isn't particularly necessary for 128. I took it after EE 20 and ME 132 (the ME prerequisite) and did fine. And a lot of the material in 132 overlaps with EE 20 (and apparently even more with 16b) so it shouldn't be particularly hard to skip it.

history.content:
I'm really interested in studying control theory, but I've heard that taking more math classes (especially linear algebra i presume) pays a lot of dividends later on. Idk who's teaching 128 yet except it's gonna be someone from the MechE department and idk what that will mean. On the other hand I heard the professor for 110 next semester is really good. Both are considered to be pretty good classes so I'm kinda conflicted.  

Thoughts? Is it possible to self learn the material from either of these?
history.subject: Math 110 or EE C128 for control theory
